awd_titl_txt: REU Site: UC Davis Chemistry Research Experience for Undergraduates in Energy and Catalysis
awd_abstract_narration:
This Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) site award to the University of California-Davis, located in Davis, CA, supports the training of 28 total students for 10 weeks during the summers of 2020-2022. This program, supported by the Division of Chemistry in the Mathematical and Physical Sciences Directorate, engages students with research projects at the interface of energy, materials science and biotechnology. Participants also take part in interactive development workshops to improve scientific communication skills, provide career guidance, and bolster capacity to perform science in a professional setting. This site offers additional multi-level mentoring and resources to accommodate blind and vision-impaired students.

Students engage in unique research projects in energy-related, fundamental and applied chemistry with expert chemistry researchers. Examples of research projects include synthesis of molecular and heterogenous catalysts; fabrication of artificial photosynthesis devices from inexpensive nanomaterials; protein engineering and synthetic biology for biofuel production; and computational modeling and simulations for enzyme and catalyst design. Graduate school and professional development programs include seminars on the search for suitable graduate programs and identifying keys for success in graduate school and beyond. The site is committed to broadening participation in STEM by promoting participation of first-generation, underrepresented minority, blind and vision impaired, and female undergraduate students from local community colleges, primarily undergraduate institutions, and minority-serving institutions such as the University of Puerto Rico.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SITE-Res Exp for Ugrd Site

por.por_cntn:
In this project, funded by the REU Sites Program in the Chemistry Division of the National Science Foundation, Professors Jesus Velazquez and Annaliese Franz have developed the University of California, Davis ChemEnergy REU site. The program is designed to provide diverse undergraduate students with a unique ten-week research experience that emphasizes chemistry at the intersection of energy, materials chemistry, and biotechnology.

Our ChemEnergy REU site aims to create a collaborative cohort experience that bridges different chemistry disciplines, concentrating on the fundamentals and applications of energy, catalysis, and enzymes.The ChemEnergy REU program has the experience, resources, and multi-level mentoring necessary to support students who are blind or vision-impaired in their research endeavors. REU students in the program will gain 1) skills in critical thinking and science communication, 2) the ability to work effectively as part of a research team, and 3) an understanding of the broader implications of chemistry and its connections to real-world issues. Overall, the experience is designed to provide students with a solid foundation for future careers in chemistry and energy sciences.

Publications

1.    Souza, L.W.; Miller, B.R.; Cammarota, R.C.; Lo, A.; Lopez, I.; Shiue, Y.; Bergstrom, B.D.; Dishman, S.N.; Fettinger, J.C.; Sigman, M.S.; Shaw, J.T. Deconvoluting Nonlinear Catalyst-Substrate Effects in the Intramolecular Dirhodium-Catalyzed C-H Insertion of Donor/Donor Carbenes Using Data Science Tools. ACS Catal. 2024, 14 (1), 104-115. DOI: 10.1021/acscatal.3c04256

2.    Ruiz, J.; Turner, D.; Gao, M.; Guo, W.; Shahvali, T.; Jimenez Andrade, E. Enantioselective Synthesis of Complex Carbocycles by Donor/Donor Carbenes C-H insertion. ChemRxiv. 2025; DOI:10.26434/chemrxiv-2025-b1fh6 This content is a preprint and has not been peer-reviewed.

3.    Siegel, R.E.; Aceves, M.; Berben, L.A. Direct Electrochemical Conversion of CO2 Sorbent Solution to Formate by a Molecular Iron Catalyst. Acs Energy Letters. 2024, 9, 6, 2896-2901. DOI: 10.1021/acsenergylett.4c00901

4.    Lee, K.Y.C.; Polyansky, D.E.; Grills, D.C.; Fettinger, J.C.; Aceves, M.; Berben, L.A. Catalyst Protonation Changes the Mechanism of Electrochemical Hydride Transfer to CO2. ACS Organic & Inorganic Au. 2024, 4, 6, 649-657.

5.    Smiley, R.E.; Mason, K.G.; Lam, R.A.; Giem, A.; Ingargiola, D.; Wuille Bille, B.A.; Prendergast, D.; Velazquez, J.M. Microwave-Assisted Intercalation: Exploring Electronic and Structural Features of Metastable MMo6S8 (M = Ag,Sn). Materials Advances. 2025. Advance Article. DOI: 10.1039/D4MA01090F

6.    Mason, K.G.; Mosqueda, N.; Vigil, A.; Del Pozo-Gonzalez, P.N.; Feiner, S.; Robinson, K.P.; Ynzunza, J.M.; Kumari, A.; Smiley, R.E.; La Plate, E.; Agbeworvi, G.; Moreno-Hernandez, I.A.; Velazquez, J.M. Chain Charge Transfer Elucidation in Quaternary Chevrel Sulfides: A Model Periodic Solid to Establish Composition-Structure-Function Relationships. In prep.

7.    Brower, R.S.; Wuille Bille, B.A.; Perryman, J.T.; Yao, C.A.; Nagasaka, C.A.; Gomez, R.; Agboola, F.; Neumann, E.; McCrory, C.C.L.; Velazquez, J.M. Selective Electrochemical Reduction of CO2 to Oxalate in Non-Aqueous Solutions using Trace Metal Pb on Carbon Supports Enhanced by a Hydrophobic Microenvironment. Paper Submitted.

Outcomes

The UC Davis ChemEnergy REU program (2020-2024), provided a diverse group of 30 undergraduate students—primarily from institutions that do not grant PhDs—with a research experience titled "Energy and Catalysis" in the Chemistry Department. This program facilitated cooperative learning among students and laboratories involved, fostered a cohort experience, and reinforced important academic and professional concepts aimed at creating a lasting impact on the students' education.

Each year, we recruited highly qualified students (average GPA = 3.7), with strong representation from underrepresented minorities (19/30, or 64%) and a gender balance (20 females, 10 males). We were able to offer an engaging program with robust components by collaborating with various opportunities provided for our NSF LSAMP, McNair, and UC-HBCU scholars at UC Davis. REU students participated in weekly seminars and workshops focused on professional development, presented by our faculty mentors. Students participated in an ice cream "happy hour" with the department, helping students feel integrated into our community. Workshop topics included "Getting into Graduate School," "Writing a Personal Statement," "Thriving and Surviving Graduate School," "Science Communication," and "How to Make a Poster." We organized a field trip to the Tahoe Environmental Research Center and held an REU Symposium featuring a poster session and a reception. Programming also included attending research group meetings and weekly one-on-one mentoring with graduate mentors and faculty.

More than half of the students presented their REU research at their home institutions upon returning. We provided funding to support their participation in regional and national ACS conferences. Several students presented at the ACS National Meetings, SACNAS, the Annual Biomedical Research Conference for Minority Students (ABRCMS), and the National Organization for the Professional Advancement of Black Chemists and Chemical Engineers (NOBBCChE). Some REU students received national awards, including NSF GRFP and ACS travel awards. Several publications now feature REU students as co-authors, listed above.

Throughout this program, we successfully supported students in developing their understanding of energy and catalysis, enhancing their professional development and communication skills, and fostering a sense of belonging within the chemistry community during these unprecedented times.

 


Last Modified: 02/26/2025
Modified by: Jesus Velazquez
